title: CREDIT CONSTRAINTS, FIRM PERFORMANCE AND CONSUMERS
abstractText:
Many firms are credit constrained - especially in the current financial climate. This research project analyses the impact credit constraints have on how firms structure their dealings with their partners in the supply chain; and hence how imperfect capital markets can impact consumer surplus through the real economy.

The investigators will embed the leading understanding of credit constraints into a supply chain contracting model and so aim to address:

  • Do credit constrained firms with investment opportunities charge too high prices?
  • Do credit constraints allow larger firms to agree lower per unit input prices? And to invest more?
  • Does tight money (high interest rates) raise consumer prices while also lowering investment levels?
  • Do credit constrained firms exposed to market risk wish to outsource or insource operations?
  • Should credit constrained firms seek 'slotting fees' or risk sharing partnerships?
  • What is the optimal way for such contracts to be structured?
  • Do credit constraints make firms vulnerable to exclusive deals?
  • Do such exclusive deals bundled with a risk sharing partnership lower consumer welfare (via higher prices), or raise it (via increased investment)?
